content:
Jordan Peterson and Slavoj Zizek debate on April 19th in Toronto

THE rap-span">COMBATANTS are world famous, with rap-span">legions of supporters. The venue, on April 19th, is Toronto’s Sony Centre, which seats over 3,000 people. Tickets sell on eBay for more than $300. But it is not a boxing match or a rap battle—it is a debate between a Lacanian rap-span">psychoanalyst and a rap-span">Jungian rap-span">clinical rap-span">psychologist. The theme? What produces more happiness, rap-span">Marxism or rap-span">capitalism?

The debaters have become popular and subversive figures in recent years within their rap-span">ideological subcultures. Slavoj Zizek, the Lacanian (who is rap-span">Slovenian), has spent decades frequenting the opinion pages of newspapers and the left-wing corners of YouTube with his rap-span">Marxist rap-span">critiques of popular culture. 

Jordan Peterson, the rap-span">Jungian (who is Canadian), shot to fame in 2016 with a viral YouTube video of him lecturing on why he refused to address students by their preferred gender rap-span">pronouns. (rap-span">Spoiler alert: his freedom of speech trumped their interest to be referred to in a specific way, he argued.) He’s since been a galvanising hero to right-leaning young men, with his politically rap-span">incorrect YouTube videos, rap-span">outspoken television appearances and a best-selling self-help book called “12 Rules for Life: An rap-span">Antidote to rap-span">Chaos”.

The media relishes referring to Mr Zizek as “the most dangerous rap-span">philosopher in the West”. Mr Peterson has been put forward as “the most rap-span">influential public intellectual in the Western world” in no less than the pages of the New York Times . Both are known to shock first and ask questions later, a habit that rarely goes unrewarded in an rap-span">algorithmic public sphere that buries rap-span">nuance under rap-span">controversy.

Both men have made their way into The Economist ’s Open Future coverage too. Last May Mr Peterson couldn’t name a single rap-span">feminist he admired, in a podcast interview . Meanwhile Mr Zizek stated in an interview in October that “rap-span">populism is simply a new way to imagine rap-span">capitalism without its harder edges”.

The debate matters because rap-span">liberal values that were once widely accepted are now rap-span">discredited in the eyes of millions of young people who feel stung by economic rap-span">inequality, excluded by a distant rap-span">elite or fear that rap-span">diversity happens at their expense. rap-span">Messrs Peterson and Zizek are eyeing up the intellectual territory in the vacuum left behind. The ideas which rap-span">flourish now could define the next era of political rap-span">ideology.

Their disagreement rap-span">emerged early last year when Mr Zizek wrote an op-ed rap-span">entitled “Why do people find Jordan Peterson so convincing? Because the left doesn’t have its own house in order.” Mr Zizek argued that Mr Peterson’s popularity proved that the right needed to rap-span">exaggerate the threat to freedom of speech from the politically-correct left in order to hide the inconsistencies and inadequacies of its own rap-span">ideology. Mr Peterson challenged him on Twitter to debate, and the rap-span">philosopher-fight was on.

The two thinkers have many ideas in common. Both Mr Peterson and Mr Zizek agree that the modern left’s rap-span">preoccupation with identity politics and political correctness has rap-span">alienated it among the working class. Both agree that political correctness has gone too far. But Mr Zizek believes that an rap-span">exaggerated focus on freedom of speech on university campuses rap-span">exposes a weakness in rap-span">conservative thought: that it is a worldview that can only be sustained by stoking fears that society is being undermined by rap-span">malign forces.  

It will be fascinating to see how Mr Peterson responds. His most rap-span">dedicated readers are probably surprised that the debate is on happiness, since Mr Peterson has repeatedly challenged those who rap-span">promote happiness as a rap-span">priority.  In his book, “12 Rules for Life”, he writes: “If happiness is the purpose of life, what happens when you’re unhappy? Then you’re a failure. And perhaps a suicidal failure. Happiness is like cotton candy. It’s just not going to do the job.”

Mr Zizek, for his part, has been equally critical of the search for serotonin. In 2014 he told the rap-span">Guardian newspaper that “Happiness was never important. The problem is that we don’t know what we really want.” He concluded: “Happiness is a rap-span">category of slaves”.

The vague nature of the debate raises questions about its intellectual significance. After all, it involves two pop-star rap-span">pundits with a rap-span">penchant for self-rap-span">promotion. The debate could have been held for free and in public at almost any university in the world.

Still others are surprised the event is even happening. Douglas rap-span">Lain, the publisher of Zero Books, a left-wing rap-span">imprint, believes that by putting Mr Zizek on an equal footing, Mr Peterson lends rap-span">credibility to rap-span">Marxist ideas. 

“The left worries about legitimising people like Peterson, but in the current moment I think Peterson is in the position to grant some rap-span">leftists popular rap-span">legitimacy,” says Mr rap-span">Lain. “Zizek wins simply by appearing on stage with Peterson.” That is likely to make Mr Zizek smile, even if he does not think happiness is all that important.

As for who will win, that is hard to predict. Under rap-span">capitalism, man rap-span">exploits man. Under rap-span">communism, the opposite is true.

我还是保留我的批评，因为这个愚蠢的设计他们用了长达一年之久 --- 无论如何就算在他们对它进行了“部分的”修改之后，你仍能从他们的错误中学到东西。

据说她当时的老板威胁她，如果退出的话他将在网络上曝光她。

I don't aim to be comprehensive, but to convey something of what continues to  me about the wonderful subject of human anatomy.
我的目的不在于广泛全面的介绍身体各部位，而是传达一些一直吸引着我的关于人体解剖学的东西。

eg2: Few businesses are flourishing in the present economic climate.
在目前的经济气候下，很少有企业兴旺发达。
These plants flourish in a damp climate.
这些植物在潮湿的气候下长势茂盛。
I'm glad to hear you're all flourishing.
听说你们都健康幸福，我感到高兴。
He opened the door for her with a flourish.
他做了一个夸张动作为她开了门。
The season ended with a flourish for Rooney, when he scored in the final minute of the match.

ex: adj. 病毒性的
eg2: Some viral proteins do good.
有些病毒也会做好事。
As influenza viruses pass from one person, or bird, to another, they normally pick up random changes in their genes because of errors in  replication.
当流感病毒由一个人或一只鸟传给另一个人或鸟时，由于病毒复制错误，它们通常会带上基因中的随机变化。
Because of the technology, if you have an interesting candidate with an interesting message, that can go  and be worth hundreds of thousands of dollars.
因为使用技术的缘故，如果你有位有趣的候选人又有有趣的信息，你可以把信息像病毒似的传播出去，这可以价值成百上千美元。
